definitions: turn around quickly on an axis or central point continuously
draw out and twist fibers into continuous thread or yarn
present information in a particular way to influence public perception
examples: The dancer spins gracefully across the stage floor
Watch the wheel spin faster as you accelerate steadily
She learned to spin wool into fine delicate thread
The factory spins cotton fibers into strong commercial yarn
Politicians often spin stories to favor their public agenda
The company tried to spin the bad news positively

definitions: move in a continuously curving path around a central point or axis
increase or decrease rapidly in an uncontrolled accelerating manner
examples: The hawk spirals upward on the warm thermal currents
Smoke spiraled lazily from the chimney into the sky
Costs began to spiral completely out of our financial control
The situation spiraled into chaos within just three days

definitions: move or convey someone or something secretly and quickly to another place
inspire with courage, energy, or determination through emotional support
examples: They spirited the witness away to a safe location
Someone spirited the documents out of the building overnight
Her coach's words spirited the team before the championship
The crowd's enthusiasm spirited the runners toward the finish

definitions: forcefully eject saliva or other substance from the mouth
rain or snow lightly in scattered drops or flakes
say something in an angry or hostile manner with force
examples: The camel spit at tourists who came too close
He spit the bitter medicine out onto the ground
It started to spit rain just as we left
The sky was spitting snow throughout the cold afternoon
She spit out the accusation with venomous anger clearly
He spit curses at his enemies during the confrontation

definitions: deliberately hurt, annoy, or offend someone out of malice or resentment
treat with deliberate malice or ill will to cause distress
examples: She refused to help just to spite her former friend
He dated her sister to spite his ex-girlfriend deliberately
They spited their neighbors by playing loud music nightly
The child spited his parents by refusing to eat dinner

definitions: cause liquid to scatter about in drops or small quantities
move through water making a splashing sound and disturbance
display or publicize something prominently in media or advertising
examples: The children splash water at each other joyfully playing
Paint splashed on the floor during the renovation project
The ducks splash noisily in the pond every morning
We could hear him splashing around in the bathtub
The newspaper splashed the scandal across its front page
They splashed their new logo everywhere throughout the city

definitions: splash or scatter liquid or soft substance in messy irregular drops
cover a surface with scattered drops or spots of liquid messily
examples: The sauce splattered all over the kitchen wall accidentally
Blood splattered across the crime scene during the incident
Rain splattered the windshield making it difficult to see
Mud splattered their clothes as the truck drove past

definitions: join two pieces of rope, film, or other material by overlapping the ends
combine genetic material from different sources to create modified organisms
examples: The sailors learned to splice ropes together for strength
The editor spliced the film scenes together seamlessly yesterday
Scientists splice genes to create disease-resistant crops successfully
The laboratory splices DNA sequences for medical research purposes

definitions: secure and immobilize an injured body part using a rigid support device
examples: The paramedic carefully splinted the broken arm before transport
They splinted his leg using two straight wooden boards

definitions: break or cause to break into small sharp pointed fragments
separate from a larger group to form distinct smaller factions
examples: The old wooden fence splintered when hit by baseball
The explosion splintered the door into countless sharp pieces
The political party splintered over disagreements about policy direction
The organization splintered into three competing factions last year

definitions: divide or cause to divide into two or more parts or groups
end a relationship or partnership and go separate ways permanently
share something equally between two or more people or groups
examples: The lightning split the tree completely down the middle
We need to split the class into smaller discussion groups
The band split after years of creative differences emerged
They decided to split when their goals became incompatible
Let's split the bill equally among all four people
They split the lottery winnings between the syndicate members

definitions: become unfit for eating or use through decay or contamination
diminish or destroy the value or quality of something good
treat with excessive indulgence or generosity harming character development
examples: The milk will spoil if left outside the refrigerator
Fresh fruit spoils quickly in hot humid weather conditions
Don't let one mistake spoil your entire vacation experience
The rain spoiled our plans for an outdoor wedding
Grandparents often spoil their grandchildren with too many gifts
His parents spoiled him throughout his entire privileged childhood

definitions: wipe or clean something using a sponge to absorb liquid
obtain money or food from others without giving anything in return
examples: She sponged the spilled coffee from the table quickly
The nurse gently sponged his fevered forehead with water
He constantly sponges money off his wealthy older brother
She's been sponging off her parents for three years

definitions: provide financial support for an event, activity, person, or organization
formally propose or support a new member or legislative measure
examples: The company sponsors several local youth sports teams annually
She sponsors a child's education in a developing country
Senator Smith sponsored the new environmental protection bill yesterday
Two members must sponsor your application to join the club

definitions: imitate something while exaggerating its characteristics for comic effect
forge or fake electronic data to deceive security systems
examples: The comedy show spoofs popular television series every week
They spoofed the president's speech at the talent show
Hackers spoofed email addresses to steal personal information illegally
Someone spoofed his phone number to make fraudulent calls

definitions: frighten or unnerve a person or animal suddenly and unexpectedly
become frightened and behave nervously or run away in fear
examples: The loud noise spooked the horses in the stable
Don't spook the deer or they will run away
The investors spooked at the first sign of trouble
The market spooked when inflation numbers were released yesterday

definitions: wind thread, tape, or film onto a cylindrical device for storage
transfer computer data to a buffer for processing or output
examples: She carefully spooled the thread onto the wooden bobbin
The projectionist spooled the film before the movie started
The printer spools documents before printing them in order
The system spools data to prevent processing bottlenecks occurring

definitions: lift and transfer food or liquid using a spoon utensil
lie close together with one person's back against another's front
examples: She carefully spooned soup into the child's waiting mouth
He spooned sugar into his coffee cup this morning
The couple spooned contentedly on the couch watching television
They spooned together for warmth during the cold night

definitions: wear or display something in an obvious or proud manner
play in a lively, energetic way or amuse oneself actively
examples: She sports a new diamond ring on her finger
He proudly sports his championship medal around his neck
The dolphins sport in the waves near the shore
Children sported on the beach throughout the sunny afternoon

definitions: notice, identify, or recognize someone or something, often with difficulty
mark or become marked with spots or stains on surface
place someone in a particular strategic position for advantage
examples: Can you spot the difference between these two pictures?
I spotted my friend in the crowded concert venue
Coffee spotted her white shirt during the morning meeting
Rain spotted the windows making them look dirty outside
The coach spotted players in key defensive positions strategically
They spotted sentries around the perimeter for better security

definitions: illuminate with a strong beam of light directed at something
direct public attention or focus prominently onto something or someone
examples: The stage crew spotlighted the lead singer during performance
They spotlighted the artwork with bright halogen lamps carefully
The documentary spotlights environmental issues affecting our coastal regions
The report spotlights serious problems in the education system

definitions: discharge or flow out forcefully in a stream or jet
talk at tedious length about something in pompous manner
examples: Water spouted from the broken pipe flooding the basement
The whale spouted water high into the morning air
He constantly spouts his political opinions at dinner parties
She spouts poetry whenever she drinks too much wine

definitions: wrench or twist ligaments of a joint violently causing pain and swelling
examples: She sprained her ankle while hiking on uneven terrain
He sprained his wrist during the basketball game yesterday

definitions: sit, lie, or fall with limbs spread out awkwardly or carelessly
spread out over a large area in an irregular or untidy way
examples: The teenager sprawled across the couch watching television lazily
He sprawled on the grass enjoying the warm sunshine
The city sprawls for miles beyond its original boundaries
Suburbs sprawl across the valley in every possible direction

definitions: apply liquid in fine drops or particles over an area
scatter or disperse things over a wide area forcefully
examples: The gardener sprays pesticide on roses every two weeks
She sprayed perfume on her wrists before leaving home
The explosion sprayed debris across the entire parking lot
Waves spray salt water high onto the rocky cliffs

definitions: open out or extend over a progressively wider area or extent
distribute or disperse something widely among many people or places
apply a substance over a surface in an even layer
examples: The fire spread rapidly through the dry forest undergrowth
News of the scandal spread throughout the entire community
They spread rumors about their political opponents during campaign
The disease spread quickly among the unvaccinated population groups
She spread butter thickly on her warm morning toast
He spread the map out on the table carefully

definitions: engage in an activity, especially shopping or drinking, excessively and enthusiastically
examples: They went on a shopping spree during the holiday sales
The tourists spreed through expensive boutiques all afternoon long

definitions: move or jump suddenly or rapidly upward or forward
move suddenly back to original shape after being compressed
originate or arise from a particular source or cause
cause something to operate or release by a mechanism
examples: The cat springs onto the counter with surprising agility
She sprang to her feet when she heard news
The branch springs back when you release it carefully
The mattress springs provide comfortable support while you sleep
Many traditions spring from ancient cultural practices and beliefs
New problems spring from lack of proper planning beforehand
The hunter accidentally sprang the trap while walking nearby
Someone sprang the prisoners from jail during the night

definitions: scatter or pour small drops or particles of a substance over something
rain very lightly in scattered drops for a brief time
examples: She sprinkles cinnamon on her cappuccino every morning carefully
The chef sprinkled fresh herbs over the finished dish
It sprinkled briefly before the sun came out again
The forecast says it will sprinkle throughout the afternoon

definitions: run at full speed over a short distance with maximum effort
examples: The athlete sprints the final hundred meters to victory
She sprinted to catch the departing bus this morning

definitions: produce shoots or buds and begin to grow from seeds
appear or develop suddenly or in large numbers rapidly
examples: Seeds sprout quickly in warm, moist soil conditions ideally
The potatoes sprouted eyes in the dark pantry storage
New businesses sprouted throughout the revitalized downtown district area
Gray hairs sprouted seemingly overnight after the stressful period

definitions: make a person or place smarter or tidier in appearance
examples: She spruced up the living room before guests arrived
He spruced himself up for the important job interview

definitions: dig up weeds or roots using a special spade-like tool
examples: The gardener spuds dandelions from the lawn every spring
They spudded the field to remove invasive plant species

definitions: encourage or prompt someone to do something or to develop
urge a horse forward by digging spurs into its sides
examples: Competition spurred innovation in the technology sector this year
Her success spurred others to pursue their ambitious dreams
The cowboy spurred his horse into a full gallop
She spurred the horse gently to increase its pace

definitions: gush out in a sudden and forceful stream or jet
move with a sudden burst of speed or energy increase
examples: Blood spurted from the wound before applying pressure immediately
Water spurted through the hole in the garden hose
The runner spurted ahead in the final race stretch
Sales spurted during the holiday shopping season this year

definitions: observe someone or something secretly to obtain confidential information
work for a government or organization gathering secret intelligence information
examples: She caught him spying through her window last night
The detective spied on suspects from an unmarked vehicle
He spied for his country during the cold war
Double agents spy for multiple intelligence agencies simultaneously nowadays

definitions: cry out noisily and continuously like a baby or young child
blow in sudden violent gusts with rain or snow
examples: The hungry baby squalled throughout the entire night persistently
Children squalled in protest when their toys were taken
The wind squalled fiercely during the tropical storm yesterday
It squalled for hours making sailing conditions extremely dangerous

definitions: make something have straight edges and right angles forming square shape
multiply a number by itself to get its mathematical square
bring into agreement or settle a debt or disagreement fairly
examples: The carpenter squared the board edges with precision tools
She squared her shoulders before entering the difficult meeting
To find the area, square the length of one side
When you square five, you get twenty-five exactly
Let me square the bill with the restaurant manager
They finally squared their differences after lengthy mediation talks

definitions: crush or squeeze something with force until it becomes flat or distorted
forcefully suppress or put an end to something like rebellion or rumor
force into a space that is too small by pressing together
examples: She accidentally squashed the tomato in her grocery bag
The heavy book squashed the delicate flowers completely flat
The government squashed the rebellion before it could spread
Management quickly squashed rumors about company layoffs yesterday morning
We all squashed into the tiny elevator uncomfortably together
They squashed too many activities into one afternoon schedule

definitions: crouch or sit with knees bent and heels close to thighs
unlawfully occupy an uninhabited building or settle on land
examples: She squats down to examine the flowers more closely
Athletes squat with weights to build strong leg muscles
Homeless people squat in the abandoned warehouse during winter
They squatted on government land for over ten years

definitions: make a loud, harsh screeching sound like a bird
complain or protest loudly and persistently in annoying manner
examples: The parrot squawks whenever strangers enter the pet store
Seagulls squawked overhead as we walked along the beach
Customers squawked about the price increase all day long
She squawked to management about her working conditions constantly

definitions: make a short, high-pitched sound or cry
succeed in doing something by a very narrow margin
examples: The rusty door squeaks whenever someone opens it slowly
Mice squeak when they communicate with each other nearby
She barely squeaked through the exam with a passing grade
The team squeaked past their opponents by one point

definitions: firmly press something from opposite sides typically with fingers
manage to get into or through a restricted space with difficulty
extract liquid or substance from something by pressing it firmly
examples: She squeezed his hand reassuringly before the surgery began
Squeeze the tube from the bottom to get toothpaste
We squeezed through the narrow gap between two buildings
Can you squeeze one more person into the car?
Squeeze the lemon to get fresh juice for cooking
They squeeze olives to produce high quality olive oil

definitions: partly close eyes to see more clearly or due to bright light
look at something with eyes partly closed from different angle
examples: She squinted in the bright sunlight without her sunglasses
He squints when reading without his prescription glasses on
The artist squinted at the painting to check proportions
Children squinted through the telescope at distant stars overhead

definitions: accompany or escort someone, especially a woman, in public formally
examples: He squired her to the charity gala last Saturday evening
The gentleman squired several ladies to the opera house

definitions: cause liquid to be ejected from a small opening in thin jet
move somewhere quickly and suddenly in a darting motion
examples: The child squirted water from the toy gun playfully
Ketchup squirted out when he squeezed the bottle hard
The cat squirted through the door before it closed
Fish squirt away when they sense danger approaching quickly

definitions: thrust a knife or pointed weapon into someone or something
make a thrusting gesture or movement with a pointed object
make a sudden unplanned attempt at doing something
examples: The attacker stabbed the victim with a kitchen knife
She accidentally stabbed herself while cutting vegetables yesterday evening
He stabbed at the map with his finger repeatedly
She stabbed the air with her pen to emphasize points
Let me take a stab at solving this problem
He made a stab at writing poetry last year

definitions: make or become unlikely to change, move, or fail in stability
examples: The medication helps stabilise her blood pressure at normal levels
Engineers worked to stabilise the damaged bridge structure immediately

definitions: make or become unlikely to give way or overturn maintaining steady position
examples: The government acted to stabilize the currency exchange rate
Her condition finally stabilized after several hours of treatment

definitions: put or keep horses in a building for lodging and feeding
examples: They stable their horses at the local riding club
The ranch stables over fifty horses throughout the year
